Posts.Content: It wouldn't hurt to drink more water. I drink allot of water during the day even before my surgery. It's good just to clean out your system. I drink a few cups of coffee a day and don't really drink any alcohol. I don't think drinking either would be bad, but that is my opinion. Drinking allot is just not good for your body though. I was doing kegels 3 times a day and went down to twice a day. Three times a day was too much for me. I would get sore. Also, you are onlyl 4 weeks post. Give it some time. I am 7 weeks post op and still have minor leaking, sometimes when I walk, but mainly when I exert myself. Good luck!!

Posts.Title: Happy Thanksgiving

Posts.Content: There are so many mixed reviews on whether Test wakes up or even feeds cancer. I have been on Test for years with no issue's and a few months ago is when I when I found out I had PC. My Uro wanted me to get off of test right away and told me that I can get back on it once my prostate is removed and I have a few PSA checks for the next few months or so. I talked to another Uro and he told me that I didn't have to get off of the test, but I got off anyhow just for now. I plan on getting back on when my Uro gives me the green light. Neither Uro feels that the test caused me to get PC. Some new studies that I have read on the internet is when your Test levels start going down, your chance of PC goes up. There is nothing in stone though at this point with either logic. BTW, I injected Test Cyp. 200 MG every week. What is your age anyhow?

Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: I couldn't wait till Wednesday to write this, but this Wednesday will be 6 weeks since my open radical prostatectomy. It' seems like it has been longer than that. I am going to start working out again today. My uro said that 6 weeks post surgery that I can go back to my normal routine. I am going to use very light weight and go easy the first few weeks. My body feels to be 100%. I am about 85 to 90% continent I believe. It gets better every day. The jury is still out on ED. I haven't really concerned myself with it although I know my wife is concerned. I'm just not ready to try anything until I get fully continent again. I can honestly say that the worst part of this was the worrying and the catheter, everything else was easy. I go mid January for my follow up. I just hope my PSA reading is zero.

Posts.Title: I got the results of my CT scan and they are normal.

Posts.Content: Just getting back from my Euro followup and the CT scan came back clean. Thank goodness for that. I talked to my euro for quite a long time. He feels that removal of my prostate is what he would recommend. He only does open surgery and not the robotic. He doesn't do the robotic but said if I opt for that to make sure I get a doctor that has done allot of them. He has a doctor that he can recommend that all he does is robotic. He also wants me to speak with another euro before I make a decision. My current euro has done a few thousand of the open surgeries. He has been a euro for 30 years. He feels that either way I go that there is no real difference in success rates doing open or robotic, he said that there will be a few more weeks of recovery time doing open. We did briefly discuss radiation implants, but he said at my age, he would do it, he just feels removal would be better for me. He explained things to me very well which I liked.

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Question

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with prostate cancer a few months ago and it really changed my life. I was very depressed over the whole thing when I first found out, but didn't let it get me down. I'm the one that thinks it will never happen to me. I have no family history of prostate cancer so the news really shocked me when I found out I had it. After talking to my Uro after the fact, like he explained, of what they could see of the biopsy, the cancer was contained in the prostate. So common sense told me, why not take the prostate out and get that cancer out of me. That would also leave radiation follow up after the fact just in case. It was a no brainer for me. The question I did have was to go open or robotic. Since I really liked my Uro and he has only does open, I went with open. I did talk to another Uro that does both but did not feel as comfortable with him. And like they both said, the outcome is pretty much the same. I didn't waste much time and made the appointment to have it removed. I have to say, the hardest part of the surgery was the day before only being able to drink clear fluids. I like to eat. When I got to the hospital and went into my pre-op changing room, they gave me a robe to change into and I shut the door to change. That is when it all hit me. I started to get very depressed. I got on my knees and prayed to God to hold my hand throughout the process. God has always been there for me and I know he always will be. I got changed and let the nurses in so they could prep me. All of the nurses talking to me really helped calm me down. Once they prepped me, they let my wife in so she could be with me prior to the surgery. After about 15 minutes, they came in to get me to take me to surgery. They gave me some drugs to calm my nerves before going into the surgery room. Before I knew it, I was in post op feeling really out of it, but no pain whatsoever. They wheeled me up to my room and my wife was there. She talked to the Uro and he said that the operation went perfect and that all the tissue's looked very healthy. My surgery was at 12:30 pm and I was in my hospital room by about 4 pm. After surgery, my diet was strictly ice shavings, which was ok since I didn't have an appetite after all I have been through. The main thing they want you to do after surgery is to get up and walk around. That night I made myself walk around the hospital. I was going to do whatever they wanted me to. I wasn't in much pain when I walked, but my legs felt a little sluggish, but that went away fairly quick. The next day I walk throughout the day. The hardest part was carrying the catheter bag around along with the IV stand. The next day, my Uro came in to see me to see how I was doing and he was very happy to see me smiling and doing so well. He gave me the green light to eat what I wanted. He was very optimistic about my surgery and told me that he feels that that in December, this will just be blimp in the radar for me. I don't want to get too long winded here, but wanted to hopefully give others some peace of mind. I'm not out of the woods yet, but so far things are looking good. I am the biggest baby when it comes to stuff like this but with the grace of Jesus Christ, I made it to this point and feel confident I will continue to improve as the years go by. I could not have made it this far without him. He is my rock. Thank all of you on this board for your support. You don't how much that has helped me and I will keep updating everyone as things move forward.

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: It's been 1 week and 1 day since surgery and I do have my ups and downs. My appetite is almost non existent. I have no real appetite for anything. I used to love bacon and eggs and now I have to force them down. I'm not sleeping through the night. The night before I felt like I as fighting a cold. I fell asleep at 1pm and woke up at 6 am covered in sweat. I stopped taking Tylenol as of yesterday morning and as of now don't feel like I need any pain killers. Last night I slept through the night which made me happy. My back aches, probably from the position I was in for the procedure and sitting around so much. The swelling in my lower regions has gone down quite a bit. I wish I had more energy. I sit in my chair all day and have to force myself to get up and do some walking. Really weird. I felt better the day after surgery than I do now. I'm thinking maybe the anesthesia has allot to do with my issue's?

Posts.Title: My surgery is in a few days

Posts.Content: Tomorrow will be 1 week since I had the surgery. A few things I have noticed since getting released on Friday. The soreness has gotten worse. I don't really have pain, just sore. My appetite is slowly starting to come back. I would say I eat about half as many calories now as I did before surgery. Passing gas hurts. I noticed today when I had a bowel movement, I must have pushed a little and saw some urine stream out between the catheter and the penis. My wife is going to stop at my Uro to get a script and will let them know about that. I don't know if that is normal or not. I've been staying in a recliner for the most part. I get up every so often and walk around. I don't really feel like doing anything. When I do try to get out of the recliner, there is some pain in my abdomen. Yesterday, I was getting momentary aches over my body that would last for a second or 2. Last night I was feeling like I was fighting a cold and got up this morning and feel the same way. The swelling at the underneath my scrotum seems to be getting a little better. This was the worst part. It just felt weird, like I was sitting on something. Yesterday was the first day that I did not nap throughout the day. Sleeping at night has been rough. I'll fall asleep for a few hours then get up. I have a hard time getting back to sleep. Last night was the first night I slept throughout the night. I did get up occasionally but was able to fall back asleep. The only pain meds that I have been on since I got released was Tylenol every 6 hours. I really don't want to take anything stronger if I don't have to. I think if I would take a vicodin at night, I may sleep better. I will say now when I have to cough or sneeze, it's a new adventure in pain. This is where I am at right now. I'll keep everyone posted.

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with prostate cancer a few months ago and it really changed my life. I was very depressed over the whole thing when I first found out, but didn't let it get me down. I'm the one that thinks it will never happen to me. I have no family history of prostate cancer so the news really shocked me when I found out I had it. After talking to my Uro after the fact, like he explained, of what they could see of the biopsy, the cancer was contained in the prostate. So common sense told me, why not take the prostate out and get that cancer out of me. That would also leave radiation follow up after the fact just in case. It was a no brainer for me. The question I did have was to go open or robotic. Since I really liked my Uro and he has only does open, I went with open. I did talk to another Uro that does both but did not feel as comfortable with him. And like they both said, the outcome is pretty much the same. I didn't waste much time and made the appointment to have it removed. I have to say, the hardest part of the surgery was the day before only being able to drink clear fluids. I like to eat. When I got to the hospital and went into my pre-op changing room, they gave me a robe to change into and I shut the door to change. That is when it all hit me. I started to get very depressed. I got on my knees and prayed to God to hold my hand throughout the process. God has always been there for me and I know he always will be. I got changed and let the nurses in so they could prep me. All of the nurses talking to me really helped calm me down. Once they prepped me, they let my wife in so she could be with me prior to the surgery. After about 15 minutes, they came in to get me to take me to surgery. They gave me some drugs to calm my nerves before going into the surgery room. Before I knew it, I was in post op feeling really out of it, but no pain whatsoever. They wheeled me up to my room and my wife was there. She talked to the Uro and he said that the operation went perfect and that all the tissue's looked very healthy. My surgery was at 12:30 pm and I was in my hospital room by about 4 pm. After surgery, my diet was strictly ice shavings, which was ok since I didn't have an appetite after all I have been through. The main thing they want you to do after surgery is to get up and walk around. That night I made myself walk around the hospital. I was going to do whatever they wanted me to. I wasn't in much pain when I walked, but my legs felt a little sluggish, but that went away fairly quick. The next day I walk throughout the day. The hardest part was carrying the catheter bag around along with the IV stand. The next day, my Uro came in to see me to see how I was doing and he was very happy to see me smiling and doing so well. He gave me the green light to eat what I wanted. He was very optimistic about my surgery and told me that he feels that that in December, this will just be blimp in the radar for me. I don't want to get too long winded here, but wanted to hopefully give others some peace of mind. I'm not out of the woods yet, but so far things are looking good. I am the biggest baby when it comes to stuff like this but with the grace of Jesus Christ, I made it to this point and feel confident I will continue to improve as the years go by. I could not have made it this far without him. He is my rock. Thank all of you on this board for your support. You don't how much that has helped me and I will keep updating everyone as things move forward.

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: Tomorrow will be 1 week since I had the surgery. A few things I have noticed since getting released on Friday. The soreness has gotten worse. I don't really have pain, just sore. My appetite is slowly starting to come back. I would say I eat about half as many calories now as I did before surgery. Passing gas hurts. I noticed today when I had a bowel movement, I must have pushed a little and saw some urine stream out between the catheter and the penis. My wife is going to stop at my Uro to get a script and will let them know about that. I don't know if that is normal or not. I've been staying in a recliner for the most part. I get up every so often and walk around. I don't really feel like doing anything. When I do try to get out of the recliner, there is some pain in my abdomen. Yesterday, I was getting momentary aches over my body that would last for a second or 2. Last night I was feeling like I was fighting a cold and got up this morning and feel the same way. The swelling at the underneath my scrotum seems to be getting a little better. This was the worst part. It just felt weird, like I was sitting on something. Yesterday was the first day that I did not nap throughout the day. Sleeping at night has been rough. I'll fall asleep for a few hours then get up. I have a hard time getting back to sleep. Last night was the first night I slept throughout the night. I did get up occasionally but was able to fall back asleep. The only pain meds that I have been on since I got released was Tylenol every 6 hours. I really don't want to take anything stronger if I don't have to. I think if I would take a vicodin at night, I may sleep better. I will say now when I have to cough or sneeze, it's a new adventure in pain. This is where I am at right now. I'll keep everyone posted.

Posts.Title: I've been pad free now for a month or so

Posts.Content: I had my open prostatectomy late 2014 and just realized that I haven't wore a incontinence pad now for over a month. One day I decided not to wear one and didn't think much of it after that. I really thought about it today that I haven't wore one for quite some time. I still have the occasional dribble after urinating since I am impatient, but other than that, no leaks, even when stressing my body or coughing. That's a big milestone for me. I'm still working on the erection issue though. I had minor issue's prior to the surgery and it got a little worse after surgery, but it is improving. I may have to bite the bullet and get some Cialas. A month's supply will cost me $55, but compared to what other people are paying, that's not a bad price. Also, my last PSA test was negative. That's the big thing to me is keep it that way.

The swelling in my lower regions has gone down quite a bit. I wish I had more energy. I sit in my chair all day and have to force myself to get up and do some walking. Really weird. I felt better the day after surgery than I do now. I'm thinking maybe the anesthesia has allot to do with my issue's?

Posts.Title: Danger of a Biopsy; allowing bad cells to spread and grow elsewhere....

Posts.Content: I have been on testosterone replacement therapy (TRT) years before getting diagnosed for PC. My Uro told me to stop the therapy for now. He said once the prostate was removed that we could talk about me getting back on it, just not sure how soon. I've been doing allot of reading about testosterone therapy and now I am reading allot that new studies are showing that there is no real connection between PC and TRT. At one time they believed that TRT can fuel the cancer but now I am reading otherwise. None of this is 100%. I want to get back on TRT. It made me feel great. Since I got off of it I get tired easy, I don't have the motivation or the frame of mind that I had while on it.

Posts.Title: Want the real expectation for Prostate removal

Posts.Content: First of all, I am 49 years old and my family does not have any history of prostate cancer. Over the past few months, I have been getting my PSA levels checked. This started because I was having a burning sensation when urinating. My PSA level's fluctuated between 4.5 and as high as 6. I had a biopsy done and out of the 12 cores, 2 of them were positive for cancer. My Gleason score is 6 and the cores where at 50%. The 2 cores that tested positive came from the right lobe of the prostate. Allot of this is new to me, so I am still learning. I will be having a CT scan done in the next week or so to see if the cancer possibly spread. Of what I heard, since my score is 6 which is considered low risk, it more than likely did not spread yet. I know I am jumping the gun, but what are good options for treatment? If it was up to me, I would rather just have the prostate removed if this will remove the cancer, but I am concerned about possible side effects. If they do remove my prostate, will they also remove my lymph nodes?

AgeInfo.Phrase: First of all  I am 49 years old and my family

Posts.Title: Unfortunately, I had to join this forum. :(

Posts.Content: Thank you all for you input and being there. I've been sick over this since I got the news this afternoon. I was on testosterone therapy for the past 5 year due to very low testosterone levels. For right now, I have to discontinue that therapy since it would feed the cancer. The doctor did say if I get rid of the cancer, I could possibly go back on. I'm worried about coming off and my hormones going out of wack, but I have no choice. Between this PC news and coming off the test, I don't want to turn into a train wreck. I talked to the nurse at the doctors office to get more info and just to talk and the one thing I thought and she said the same thing, if I have the prostate removed, it removes the cancer and I'm pretty much cancer free. It seems like a no brainer. Am I missing something here? Since all treatment have about the same sides, why not? I don't plan on having anymore kids. How will this effect my sex though?
